From our school assembly earlier this year where we focused on human rights movements around the world.

In the 1920's, the Mau Movement was a non-violent movement for Samoan independence. The motto of the Mau was Samoa mo Samoa, which meant Samoans for Samoa. They were a peaceful organization, but despite their efforts for non-violence, they were met with violence in 1929 on the street capital of Apia, when the New Zealand military fired into their peaceful demonstration, killing 11 Samoans including the Mau Movement leader and high chief Tupua Tamasese Lealofi III.

The song Tamasese was composed about this day to honor the courage and bravery of those who stood for Samoan Independence.

Music: Mana Scholars
Dancers: Mana Scholars
Choreography: Feagaiga O Ali'i

Mana Academy has one of the largest Marshallese student population in a school here in Utah. We follow closely everything that happens in the Marshall Islands because our scholars are closely connected to their families back home. Recently, the Marshall Islands was declared a war zone due to the huge waves that displaced over 200 families from their homes. We hear firsthand accounts from our scholars who experienced displacement and loss due to climate change. The majority of our Marshallese scholars have at least one or more family members who are currently suffering from health complications due to the effects of nuclear testing in the Marshall Island.

When our scholars sing this song, Ibwijleplep, they know and understand what this means for themselves and their classmates. We hope the voices of our scholars carries the mana of this song to everyone who is at the frontlines in the Marshall Islands ‚ù§

Mana Academy has one of the largest Marshallese student population in a school here in Utah. We follow closely everything that happens in the Marshall Islands because our scholars are closely connected to their families back home. Recently, the Marshall Islands was declared a war zone due to the huge waves that displaced over 200 families from their homes. We hear firsthand accounts from our scholars who experienced displacement and loss due to climate change. The majority of our Marshallese scholars have at least one or more family members who are currently suffering from health complications due to the effects of nuclear testing in the Marshall Island.

When our scholars sing this song, Ibwijleplep, they know and understand what this means for themselves and their classmates. We hope the voices of our scholars carries the mana of this song to everyone who is at the frontlines in the Marshall Islands ‚ù§

Thank you to the original song writers; Dometo Notarianni-Dometo, Citizen and GX records for giving us permission to sing their song. #ManaScholars #ManaAcademy #Ibwijleplep üá≤üá≠

Our Mana Scholars singing the late Tongan Queen Salote's composition - Tuaikaepau.

In July 1962 the Tuaikaepau was under sail between Tonga and Auckland when it hit the outer edge of the Southern Minerva Reef. For 102 days, the men who were on the ship worked together to stay alive. Eventually, three of the survivors made a makeshift vessel from parts of a Japanese ship that crashed on the reef two years earlier, which took them to Kadavu, Fiji and eventually led to the rescue of the remaining survivors on October 16, 1962. It is a remarkable story about the strength and the will to live and to survive. Princess Salote was only two years of age when her mother died on April 25th, 1902. On October 11, 1918, at the age of 18, she was crowned Queen Salote Tupou III of the Kingdom of Tonga and ruled for 47 years, as the longest monarch in Tongan history before her passing in 1965.

In this Science project, our 8th grade scholars learned about chemical reactions by using tools of scientific research to explore how different substances interact. They also had to design a plan to collect data, and then use the data as evidence to support their conclusions in a formal lab report. Scholars were assessed on the cognitive skills of Asking Questions, Predicting/ Hypothesizing, Designing Processes and Procedures, Identifying Patterns and Relationships, Interpreting Data/Info and Explanation of Evidence. In addition, students had to master the content areas of Chemical Reactions and Structure and Properties of Matter.

post_text: How does human activity impact our environment? How can humans reverse the damage they do to the environment? In this Biology project, our 9th grade scholars explored the impact of electronic waste and toxins on the the planet's environment. Scholars learned about the toxic chemicals that are in many of the popular electronic gadgets and assume the role of an electronics owner tasked with the responsibility of findings ways to reduce the negative impact of electronics on the health and environment. Scholars then shared their findings in a Socratic Seminar and also presented on The Ethics of E-Waste to the 6th grade scholars. Scholars were assess on the cognitive skills of Explanation of Evidence, Discussion/Contribution, Preparation, and Norms/Active Listening. They also had to master the content areas of Matter Cycling and Energy Flow, Ecosystem Relationships and Energy Pyramid and Food Web.

post_text: In World History, our 10th grade scholars engaged in a two month, ten class period project to answer the question: Should imperial powers pay reparations to imperialized countries? They looked at the history of imperialization through the lens of the British in India and Belgium in Congo, analyzed documents from that era from the perspective of the natives and those employed by imperial powers, and prepared for a Structured Academic Controversy (debate) where teams were organized into Team For Reparations and Team Against Reparations. Afterwards, both teams came together to form a consensus. Next, they will write a timed essay on the same question in which they will be assessed on the cognitive skills of Synthesizing Multiple Sources, Argumentative Claim, Selection of Evidence, Explanation of Evidence and Integration of Evidence.

post_text: What does the movie Black Panther teach us about the human and physical geography of Africa? Our 9th grade World Geography class tackled the complexities of this inquiry question, looking at the troublesome history of Africa's past with imperialism, the Transatlantic slave trade, apartheid in South Africa, global anti-blackness and connecting those historical events to the motivations of the character, Killmonger. Scholars had to produce two final products: a Socratic Seminar which assessed the cognitive skills of Discussion/Contribution, Norms/Active Listening and Preparation, and a timed essay, a character analysis on Killmonger, which assessed the cognitive skills of Selecting Relevant Sources, Argumentative Claim and Integration of Evidence.

In Chemistry, our 10th grade scholars ponder the essential question: how do our communities and society influence our perception of chemistry?

post_text: Five years ago, we embarked on an ambitious mission to open a school in response to low academic performance in underserved communities, most noticeably, the Pacific Island community in the Salt Lake valley. Our mission and scope expanded to include other communities of color similarly affected by high rates of poverty, school dropout, incarceration, which created the many barriers responsible for the low performance. We knew that these brilliant scholars were not their circumstance. These kids were extremely capable learners stigmatized by society and situations often out of their control. We knew that we couldn't just be any school, we had to tap into the cultural values we all share‚Äìlove, family, building and maintaining strong relationships‚Äîto create a foundation that will support the conditions for high impact learning, and to build the mindsets and habits to succeed in life. We reflect on the progress we've made in the last five years through this multimedia retrospective.

Our scholars come from various ethnic backgrounds that includes South Pacific island nations, Latin American countries, African-American, Caucasian and indigenous Americans including native Hawaiians. At Mana Academy, they learn the languages, dances and songs of their own cultures but also the other cultures of our school community. Multiculturalism is not only embraced at our school but made easy by the common values we all share: reverence for the sacrifices our migrant ancestors made on our behalf, reverence for the indigenous people of this land, love, respect, collaboration, acceptance, reciprocity and the pursuit of continual self improvement. Thank you to everyone who came to support our annual cultural recital. We love our school community!

Photo credit: Office of Engagement at the University of Utah (PS, thanks for coming!)

The Mana Games come to a close and congratulations to our 9th grade scholars for winning the most medals as well as the most pages read per grade! They now are the stewards of the precious duct tape trophy and all bragging rights that come with it until the next games. The Mana Games, created to promote literacy and school spirit, kicked off on the National Day of Reading with an Opening Ceremony, complete with cheers and a team flags contest, followed by a week of games, reading challenges, history trivia, an engineering challenge, and ended with a campus wide read-a-thon. Scholars also participated in fun games during lunch for more medals. Our 9th graders won the most pages read for the week, with an average of 164 pages read per scholar. All gold medalists received Jazz tickets, courtesy of Jazz guard, Alec Burks.

Mahalo to Alec and the Jazz organization for the tickets and congratulations to all winners. We are already looking forward to next year's games!

We represent our families and communities.

We respect ourselves and all people.

We take ownership of our academic success.
We are future college graduates.
We are united.
We are family.
We are MANA!

post_text:
For their final project of the 2nd term, our STEM Flex Math Class on our secondary campus tackled the controversial issue of the School to Prison pipeline. By breaking down and deconstructing the pipeline mathematically, the students were able to expose its complex political underpinnings and social implications, with emphasis on how the pipeline has disproportionately impacted communities of color. During the term, they researched policies, the proliferation of for-profit prisons, interviewed school resource officers, their peers, faculty, presented their findings in a video and slide presentation. The process was as empowering for them as it was for our students in the audience, who gave them a rousing applause.

Bravo Mr. Rene and students!!
